PIONEER DIET: WHAT DID WESTERN CANADIAN FISHERMEN EAT?

Instructions: Please answer as many of these questions as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask., where it will be preserved as part of the permanent record of our Province.

Name: Alice W. Murray
Address: Anquith, Sask.
Birthplace: Vars, Ontario

1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS

What year did you start housekeeping in Western Canada? 1914
Where did you set up housekeeping? Anquith, Sask.
Where had you been living before that? Vars, Ontario
For how many people did you prepare meals? three
How far was it to your nearest store? 7 miles
How often could a visit be made to the store? Every two weeks
What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years? Sugar, tea, salt, raisins, rice, tapioca, syrup, dried fruit, flour, rolled oats, yeast, molasses

5. MEAT AND FISH

What was your meat supply in the early years? We raised our own.
How did you get fresh meat? We raised our own.
How often did you get fresh meat? Very seldom.
How did you preserve meat? In salt bins.

Has there a "beef ring" in your neighborhood? No.
If so what year was it organized?
Did you use game? Yes.
What kinds? Pheasant, chicken, ducks.
For how long?
What part did fish play in the family diet? We usually went for some in the winter.
Was the fish fresh, cured, or canned? Fresh, salted fish.
Kinds? Salmon, fresh & canned.

12. WATER SUPPLY

Where did you get water for drinking and for cooking? (Well, river, slough, dugout) We had a well, but had to draw some water from a neighbor's, maybe 2½ miles to 3 miles.

How far was this water from your home? ________

How was it brought to the home? (pail, barrel, tank) ________

Regarding water supply, mention any changes which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible.

In 1916 we had a well bored 83 ft. It still is the one we use, lots of water and very good.

In 1917, built a house, with water pipes for to catch rain water. Cistern water brought to kitchen by pump.

What fuel did you use in the earliest days? Mostly wood.

Where did you get your fuel? (Handwritten note: From the bush, 10 miles north of Agassiz. We used all the coal later.)

Mention any changes in the use of fuels which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible. We were using almost all coal by 1914.

16. WRAPPINGS AND CONTAINERS

Mention any changes which you recall in the wrappings and containers received with the food you purchased (give dates where possible).

Dried apples in packages. Cheese in small cartons. Packing sugar in 4 lb packages. Most raisins in packages. Spices in tins. Jam in bottles. 1914, Sept 10th.

17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner & supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family with their ages at the time. State the approximate month, e.g., winter or summer.

Breakfast, June 1910. Cracked Wheat porridge, golden syrup & toast, tea and allway rolls, milk. Dinner, Potatoes, fried smoked pork, pickles, Bread, rice pudding with big seeded raisins in it, sauce on top, Peppered potatoes, eggs, Bread, very often marble cake, rhubarb preserves.

18. What year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in Western Canada? Give the menu. List those present and give their approximate ages at that time.

Roast chicken, steam pudding, Bread, pickles. We were hailed out our first year on the prairie I was not twelve yet. My mother, father, brother & two men from away from home.

19. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details.

We have always had enough to eat. In the thirties we did not have as much as usual. There is always plenty to eat on the farm if people work for it.

Plattico. We were thrilled out our final year.

18. What did you have for breakfast?

19. Have always had enough to eat. You the "charity" we did not have as much as usual. This is always plenty to eat on the farm if people work for it.
In the early days we had to prepare all our meals every day. Now we have as many vegetables & fruits canned in the basement also plum pudding. We can get a meal ready in a very short time with very little work attached.

We don't rely on purchased food very much. That is vegetables & fruits etc except the fresh ones. I have not made much bread for the last ten yrs. But I do make buns cakes cookies & pie. We use canned tomatoes salmon tomatoes & vegetable soup little canned meat some sauce & hamburger. Meat loaf. We don't buy much fresh meat.

We bought more canned tomatoes corn & peas in the early days than we do now. So we did that then learn how to can at home.
In the early days we had to prepare all our meals every day. Now we have so many vegetables and fruits canned in the basement and plum pudding. We can get a meal ready in a hurry.
